page.title: 15ECOLOGY NORTH OF CHITTERNE
page.content: An M.O.D. sponsored, but largely civilian, conservation group records all aspects of natural history in the Military Training area which, being free of agricultural chemicals, is rich ecologically. It is active in the management of larger animals. Resident mamals include roe deer, foxes, badgers, hares, rabbits and small rodents. Sparrowhawk, buzzard, hobby, harrier, quail, partridge, pheasant and several types of owl breed in the area.A small group of garganey nest in the Beryl Valley and lapwing, golden plover and redshank contribute to a total of 87 species recorded. It is a fruitful area for butterflies and moths. In the botanical field 324 different flowering plants (including 7 types of orchid) and 3 varieties of moss have been listed.
